/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_6DECSKS_3lib_18boundaryconditions_17symmetric_lower_boundary(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_6DECSKS_3lib_18boundaryconditions_16symmetric_lower_boundary[] = "\n    This routine assumes a time substep is positive as the Vlasov-Poisson system is irreversible\n    when boundaries are present (i.e. the upper boundary cannot be periodic/open in this setup)\n\n    this boundary condition must not inherently operate on a symmetric velocity grid,\n    but it is more natural and consistent this way. Some rationale is given below:\n\n    For example, if an exiting particle at the symmetry plane has\n    a velocity V1 < 0, it is the physical case that there exists an entering partner particle from the\n    complement domain with oppositely directly velocity -V1 > 0. If a symmetric velocity\n    grid, i.e. [avx, bvx] = [-V, V], is used then it is always possible to factor in both\n    exiting (V1 < 0) density with entering partners (-V1 > 0) provided that V1 is inside [-V,V].\n\n    If we have an asymmetric case where [avx, bvx] where avx != -bvx, then in the handling\n    of the symmetry plane, there would be cases where such an exiting particle having V1 < 0 would have\n    its entering partner with velocity -V1 not be representable (i.e. if avx < V1 is in the velocity grid,\n    but bvx < -V1). We permit options so that the user may elect to take the following alternative to\n    a symmetric velocity grid, i.e.\n\n    We could still argue that it would be appropriate to handle such situations where the entering partner\n    velocity is off-grid (at too largely positive of a value for a given grid [avx, bvx])\n    then to take the partner density to be zero and interpret the  situation as the \"window\" or\n    control volume in phase space. Thus, any entering particle with off-grid velocities will not re-enter\n    the domain as their phase space coordinates are not in the simulation domain.\n\n    a CUTOFF upper boundary condition should be chosen for the distribution function on the associated\n    velocity variable for any case. CAUTION: periodic BCs on velocity for the distribution function are not\n    appropriate, as the re""flection in velocity exiting grid point j -> vz.N - 1 - j will not successfully mirror\n    to the exact grid point needed if vz.N != vz.Ngridpoints (as would be the case for periodic boundary conditions)\n    ";

 342:         np.ndarray[DTYPE_t, ndim=2] f_k,
 343:         np.ndarray[DTYPE_t, ndim=2] f_old,

 350:         int Nz, int Nvz, int k,
 351:         int charge,
 352:         sim_params,
 353:         z, vz
 354:         ):
 355: 
 356:     """
 357:     This routine assumes a time substep is positive as the Vlasov-Poisson system is irreversible
 358:     when boundaries are present (i.e. the upper boundary cannot be periodic/open in this setup)
 359: 
 360:     this boundary condition must not inherently operate on a symmetric velocity grid,
 361:     but it is more natural and consistent this way. Some rationale is given below:
 362: 
 363:     For example, if an exiting particle at the symmetry plane has
 364:     a velocity V1 < 0, it is the physical case that there exists an entering partner particle from the
 365:     complement domain with oppositely directly velocity -V1 > 0. If a symmetric velocity
 366:     grid, i.e. [avx, bvx] = [-V, V], is used then it is always possible to factor in both
 367:     exiting (V1 < 0) density with entering partners (-V1 > 0) provided that V1 is inside [-V,V].
 368: 
 369:     If we have an asymmetric case where [avx, bvx] where avx != -bvx, then in the handling
 370:     of the symmetry plane, there would be cases where such an exiting particle having V1 < 0 would have
 371:     its entering partner with velocity -V1 not be representable (i.e. if avx < V1 is in the velocity grid,
 372:     but bvx < -V1). We permit options so that the user may elect to take the following alternative to
 373:     a symmetric velocity grid, i.e.
 374: 
 375:     We could still argue that it would be appropriate to handle such situations where the entering partner
 376:     velocity is off-grid (at too largely positive of a value for a given grid [avx, bvx])
 377:     then to take the partner density to be zero and interpret the  situation as the "window" or
 378:     control volume in phase space. Thus, any entering particle with off-grid velocities will not re-enter
 379:     the domain as their phase space coordinates are not in the simulation domain.
 380: 
 381:     a CUTOFF upper boundary condition should be chosen for the distribution function on the associated
 382:     velocity variable for any case. CAUTION: periodic BCs on velocity for the distribution function are not
 383:     appropriate, as the reflection in velocity exiting grid point j -> vz.N - 1 - j will not successfully mirror
 384:     to the exact grid point needed if vz.N != vz.Ngridpoints (as would be the case for periodic boundary conditions)
 385:     """
+386:     vzpostpointmesh = vzprepointmesh.copy() # by this point, vzpostpointmesh has not been assigned (is an array of zeroes), init to prepointmesh values
  __pyx_t_2 = __Pyx_PyObject_GetAttrStr(((PyObject *)__pyx_v_vzprepointmesh), __pyx_n_s_copy); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) {__pyx_filename = __pyx_f[0]; __pyx_lineno = 386; __pyx_clineno = __LINE__; goto __pyx_L1_error;}
